citation.article-title: Reclassification of Nocardia corynebacterioides Serrano et al. 1972 (Approved Lists 1980) as Rhodococcus corynebacterioides comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Rhodococcus corynebacterioides comb. nov.
Rhodococcus corynebacterioides (co.ry.ne.bac.te.ri.oi′des. N.L. neut. n. Corynebacterium bacterial genus name; Gr. suffix -oides similar to; N.L. adj. corynebacterioides similar to Corynebacterium).
Basonym: Nocardia corynebacterioides Serrano et al. 1972 (Approved Lists 1980).
The description is based on data from previous studies (Crowle, 1962; Gordon, 1966a; Serrano et al., 1972) as well as on data obtained during this study.
Smooth, orange–red-pigmented colonies are formed on agar media.
Cells are rod- and coccoid-like, Gram-positive and partially acid–alcohol-fast.
Contains the salient chemotaxonomic characteristic of the genus Rhodococcus.
Mycolic acids are cleaved on pyrolysis to release fatty acids C14 : 0 and C16 : 0 as the major cleavage products.
Fatty acid profile mainly consists of straight-chain saturated, unsaturated and 10-methyl branched fatty acids.
Hydrolyses adenine and testosterone, but not casein, elastin, aesculin, gelatin, guanine, hypoxanthine, tyrosine, urea or xanthine.

Assimilates acetate, 2,3-butanediol, citrate, glucose, gluconate, myo-inositol, mannitol, 1,2-propanediol, sucrose, sorbitol and trehalose as carbon sources, but not adonitol, adipate, iso-amylalcohol, arabinose, cellobiose, meso-erythritol, galactose, m-hydroxybenzoate, p-hydroxybenzoate, lactate, lactose, maltose, melezitose, raffinose or rhamnose.
Xylose is weakly utilized as a carbon source.
Utilizes proline, serine and ornithine, but not acetamide, alanine, arginine or gelatin, as simultaneous carbon and nitrogen sources.
